title: Who would want to be the child of a politician in this febrile Brexit era?
text:
There is no upside to being the child of a politician, an MP once told me as he explained his reasons for standing down from the Commons. Their parents work long hours, often far from home.

They miss birthdays and school plays; family suppers are interrupted by phone calls from the whips, weekends are dominated by constituency events, evenings by late-night votes.

There are the playground taunts (especially if your mother or father has a well-known or unusual name), the ridicule if they do something unpopular.

And most of these youngsters learn at a young age that they will always come second; to the party, to the public, to the media. Politics is sometimes described as show business for ugly...
